content.text:
# Timeline of history of Assam

Timeline of the History of Assam, the important dates in its history against important events elsewhere.
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left" align="left" cellpadding="5"
! Year || Ancient Assam (350 - 1206) || Contemporaneous events || Date source
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 350
|| Pushyavarman establishes the Varman dynasty in Kamarupa
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 636
|| Xuanzang visits the court of Bhaskarvarman in Kamarupa.
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 650
|| Bhaskarvarman dies. End of Varman dynasty
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 655
|| Salasthamba establishes Mlechchha dynasty in Kamarupa
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 900
|| Brahmapala establishes Pala dynasty in Kamarupa
||
||
|-valign="top"
| c1100
|| Jayapala, the last Pala king removed by Ramapala of Pala empire
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1187
|| Birpal establishes Chutiya kingdom at Swarnagiri
||
||
|-valign="top"
! Year || Medieval Assam (1206–1826) || Contemporaneous events || Date source
|-valign="top"
|
|colspan="3"| 13th century
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1206
|| The first Muslim invasion, Bakhtiar Khilji is thwarted and his army destroyed.  Beginning of the medieval period in Assam
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1228
|| Sukaphaa enters Assam
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1224
|| Ratnadhwajpal the second Chutiya king annexes the Kingdoms of Bhadrasena and Nyayapal
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1228
|| Chutiya kingdom expedition against Kamatapur
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1248
|| Ratnadhwajpal establishes his capital at Sadiya
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1252
|| Sukaphaa establishes capital at Charaideo
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1257
|| Sandhya, a ruler of Kamarupa, moves his capital west and thus established the Kamata kingdom.
||
||
|-valign="top"
|
|colspan="3"| 14th century
|-valign="top"
|align-"right"| 1362
||Sikandar Shah attacks Kamata kingdom and weakens the ruler Indranarayan
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1392
|| Chutia king Satyanarayan's first land grant record in Habung. This is the first recorded land grant given to Brahmins in Upper Assam found till date.
||
||
|-valign="top"
|
|colspan="3"| 15th century
|-valign="top"
| align="right"|1449
|| Srimanta Sankardev is born
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1490
|| First Ahom-Dimasa battle. Ahoms defeated under Konkhra and pursued for peace.
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1498
|| Alauddin Hussain Shah of Gaur removes the last Khen ruler of Kamata kingdom
|| Vasco da Gama lands at Calicut
||
|-valign="top"
|
|colspan="3"| 16th century
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1515
|| Viswa Singha establishes Koch political power and Koch dynasty
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1520
|| Ahoms defeated by Chutiya king Dharmadhwajpal
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1524
|| Chutiya kingdom partially annexed to Ahom Kingdom under Suhungmung, and placed under the rule of Sadiyakhowa Gohain.
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1527
|| Nusrat Shah's invasion, the first Muslim invasion of the Ahom kingdom, ends in failure.
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1532
|| Turbak attacks Ahom Kingdom, the first commander to enjoy some success.
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1533
|| Turbak defeated and killed.  Ahoms pursue Gaur army to Karatoya river.
||
||
|-valign="top"
| align="right"|1536
|| Ahoms destroy Dimapur, the capital of the Kachari kingdom
||
||
|-valign="top"
| align="right"|1540
|| Nara Narayan succeeds his father to the throne of Kamata kingdom
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1563
|| Chilarai occupies Ahom capital Garhgaon, end with Treaty of Majuli.
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1568
|| Srimanta Sankardev dies
||
||
|-valign="top"
| align="right"|1581
|| Nara Narayana divides Kamata kingdom into Koch Bihar and Koch Hajo (to be governed by Raghudev)
||
||
|-valign="top"
| align="right"|1587
|| Naranarayana of Koch dynasty dies.
||
||
|-valign="top"
| align="right"|1588
|| Raghudev, son of Chilarai and ruler of Koch Hajo declares independence
||
||
|-valign="top"
|
|colspan="3"| 17th century
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1609
|| Momai Tamuli Borbarua restructures Paik system in Ahom kingdom.
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1609
|| Koch Bihar becomes a Mughal vassal
||
||
|-valign="top"jjj
|align="right"| 1613
|| Koch Hajo is annexed by the Mughal Empire
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1615
|| Ahom-Mughal conflicts begin
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1637
|| Bali Narayan dies of natural causes, and Koch rebellion again Mughals collapse
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1639
|| Treaty of Asurar Ali signed between the Ahom kingdom and Mughal Empire
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1659
|| Ahoms take possession of Koch Hajo (up to Sankosh river).  Koch Hajo was occupied by rulers of Koch Bihar earlier, who drove out the Mughal faujdar from Guwahati
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1662
|| Mir Jumla occupies Garhgaon, the Ahom capital
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1663
|| After Treaty of Ghilajharighat Mir Jumla returns to Dhaka, dies on the way
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1667
|| Ahoms wrest Guwahati and extend control up to Manas river; begins defence preparations
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1668
|| Mughals under Ram Singh I advance up to Guwahati to retake it
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1671
|| Ahoms win Battle of Saraighat and Ram Singh I retreats to Rangamati
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1679
|| Laluksola Borphukan deserts Guwahati
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1681
|| Gadadhar Singha becomes Ahom swargadeo
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1682
|| Ahoms win Battle of Itakhuli.  End of Ahom-Mughal conflicts with Ahom win
||
||
|-valign="top"
|
|colspan="3"| 18th century
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1714
|| Rudra Singha dies, and with him dies the Kachari, Tiwa, Jaintia etc. grand alliance to remove the Mughals from Bengal
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1769
|| First phase of Moamoria rebellion, Ahom capital falls but recaptured in April, 1770
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1783
|| Ahom capital Rangpur fell the second time to Moamoria rebellion.  Rebel leaders strike coins in their names
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1794
|| Captain Thomas Welsh restores Rangpur to Ahom king from Moamora rebels
||
||
|-valign="top"
|
|colspan="3"| 19th century
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1805
|| Ahoms come to terms with Sarbananda, the last Moamora rebel leader holding out in Bengmara (Tinsukia).  Ahoms declare Sarbananda the Barsenapati of Matak Rajya
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1817
|| The first Burmese invasion of Assam.  Burmese occupation was complete by 1821
||
||
|-valign="top"
! Year || Colonial Assam (1826–1947) || Contemporaneous events || Date source
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1826
|| Treaty of Yandaboo signed between East India Company and King of Burma; end of Burmese and beginning of British occupation of Assam
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1861
|| Phulaguri Dhawa, the first peasant uprising against British rule was repressed
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1894
|| Patharughat raijmel fired upon, villagers tortured and property confiscated
||
||
|-valign="top"
! Year || Post Colonial Assam (1947-)|| Contemporaneous events || Date source
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1979
|| Assam agitation begins
||
||
|-valign="top"
|align="right"| 1985
|| Assam Accord signed.  End of Assam agitation
||
||
|}
Notes
References
*
*
*
*
*
*
